Title: Tasmanian SFG: Welcome to Hell
Author: C.R. Daems
My Review:
This book is a rather heavy handed parable on the superiority of thinking before you act and managing your emotions over charging in and pretending no fear in service of tough guy bravado. It wasn't enough that every major plot point was framed with the main character triumphing over angry bumbling fools because she took two seconds to think and clam her mind, but then every person she interacted with found it necessary to summarize the moral lesson for you by way of saying how wrong they were to underestimate her and her approach and just how darned great she is.

(As a side note, I think the debates from other reviewers on sexism is a case of Poe's Law. Yes, there's plenty of over the top misogyny. But it's mostly there to demonstrate just how vile the various straw characters are. It would be like an author using the kick-the-dog trope literally, then for reviewers to get enmeshed in a debate on animal abuse.)

Even so, it was an action packed adventure that I found myself engrossed by despite myself. The characters were distinctive and likable, the fight scenes vivid, and the tone oddly lighthearted in spite of the seemingly grim context. Between the absurd proselytizing and the military theme which isn't my usual thing, I kept thinking I'd stop reading it any minute. Instead I got so caught up in the ride that I was done before I knew it.

Title: The Coldest Girl in Coldtown
Author: Holly Black
Publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
My Review:
I want to say that this was a heartwarming story, though perhaps that would not be a typical reaction.

At once a viscerally raw horror thriller, a YA paranormal romance, a pandemic apocalypse despotic, a political satire, and even a touch of a mystery. So, not your typical vampire story.

I loved Tana as a protagonist because she is neither a damsel in distress, nor an action hero, but a survivor. Almost every moment of the story she is nearly paralyzed with fear, yet in spite of that she is determined and clever. She doesn't romanticize monsters and conveniently forget the dark pasts of cute bad boys. Instead she's compassionate in a way that feels like she sees people and monsters in all their complexity, neither forgiving foibles for virtues nor dismissing all redeeming qualities in the face of transgression. Being able to really see people for who they are is key to her survival, but it also makes her kind. Plus she's sardonic with a self-deprecating inner dialog, which, y'know, I'm into.

I will say, I was a bit put off of the book at first. I got a bit of a Black Mirror vibe what with its vampire hunter reality TV shows and social media celebrity fang-bangers, and I only like that sort of black social commentary in small doses. But it turned out to be a moderately employed and well executed part of a much bigger picture.

I've been binging Holly Black's books lately and I've come to love her writing style, in this book in particular. Her quotes at the beginning of each chapter are beautiful and often eerily fitting. The world feels tangible and the characters real and flawed and full of personality. There are so many moments that surprised me and made me smile--a great word choice, a hauntingly lyrical quote, a witty piece of dialog, a plot twist I didn't see coming.

Much more to this book than I would have expected, and much more of it that I liked.

Title: A Dance with Dragons (A Song of Ice and Fire, #5)
Author: George R.R. Martin
My Review:
First, to be clear, this book is very good. It shows off Martin's talent for artfully crafting language, character development, vibrant imagery, and masterful storytelling.

But it also drove me crazy, and I didn't find myself as drawn in as I was with the other books in the series--as is evidenced by the fact that it took me six months to get through it.

If I were to identify the theme of this book, it might be something like "Our heroes of the Seven Kingdoms grow up and become burdened with the responsibilities of management." While this is perhaps an interesting and oft unexplored area of fantasy, I just couldn't get into it.

The ending of this book was terribly unsatisfying, all the more so for coming after the incomplete volume four. This is particularly maddening in contrast to the first three books of the series--one of the things that I most admired about those books is their strong independent story arc and thesis that ended so conclusively. Although they were part of a larger series, they each felt like complete and satisfying works that could stand alone. It is mystifying how the last two novels devolved so far into cliff-hangers and seemingly arbitrary endings.



Overall, I enjoyed most of the chapters as independent short stories. But as a part of the Song of Ice and Fire series I found it sub-par and exasperating.

Title: Good Sex: Getting Off Without Checking Out
Author: Jessica Graham
My Review:
As much as I like the idea of mindful sex I couldn't get into this book.

The author spends a lot of time focusing on issues that are not relevant to me like sexual trauma or orgasm shame. She also goes into some pretty intense personal stories about her own experience with these kinds of issues.

I admire her for going through that journey and sharing her experience with others. At the same time, I think it might make mindfulness practices seem unapproachable. For example, she ends the book with a story about how when she was started she was told "this is going to destroy your life." She goes on to say that "the key is to stick it out until the reconstruction can begin." That's not a great sales pitch for mindfulness, and I suspect not necessarily applicable to people who are not dealing with major trauma.

When there was advice that was more general and might apply to my situation, I found it pretty unapproachable. For example, she often suggests that the solution to an issue is to love yourself unconditionally or to realize that you are "perfect just the way you are". That's a pretty tall order without any additional information on how to get there.

Finally, I suspect that there may be a style issue. The people that she often quoted as mentors were usually from the more woo woo side of the meditation world.

This might be a good resource for some, but it just didn't gel for me.

Title: The Polyamorists Next Door: Inside Multiple-Partner Relationships and Families
Author: Elisabeth Sheff
My Review:
Ok, so I don't know much about how sociology research is typically done. But it seems that the research for this book was mostly collected through interviews of volunteers. If I was predisposed to think that polyamory is harmful to relationships and families, I would be skeptical of evidence to the contrary gathered from a self-selected, self-reporting group of advocates. But I guess you've gotta start somewhere.

With that caveat, this was a worthwhile read, albeit dry. (As I suppose one would expect from an academically oriented book.)

A lot of the content would be unsurprising to anyone with poly experience, such as the sections on the challenges that poly people face (jealousy, unicorn hunters, couple's privilege, etc) and the techniques for dealing with them (communication, honesty, agreements, etc). There were a few sections that framed issues differently than I'd thought of them before--for example, distinguishing between people who identify as poly versus people who "do" poly.

The quantitive aspect was interesting. While not terribly surprising, I was disappointed to learn how prevalent what I think of as outdated and unhealthy models of polyamory are practiced. For example, Sheff says that the majority of the people that she interviewed practice some form of hierarchy. (I do wish she had distinguished with a bit more nuance there--between descriptive versus proscriptive hierarchy and hierarchy versus priorities. But that is probably more of a statement on the state of poly nomenclature than it is on her research.)

I learned the most in the chapters dealing with poly families--that is to say, poly people with children. I had already done a fair bit of research on the subject from other sources and had previously learned that the primary challenges tend to be from social stigma--friends, parents of friends, other family members, the children themselves, and in extreme cases, loss of custody. The commonly mentioned up-sides include having more loving and supportive adults around and exposure to good communication skills.

Sheffs research included all of those, but also mentioned a number of other aspects that I hadn't heard about before. For example, children wishing for more space and privacy in larger joined poly households, the difficulty of merging complex poly households, challenges surrounding financial dependency and legal guardianship, and how to approach the close relationships that have formed between children and partners after a breakup. Most of these new-to-me issues came up in cohabiting configurations and (as Sheff points out) many of them are not unique to polyamory.

As a side note, I disliked the narration on the audio version of the book. Most of the book was read in a monotone that was almost robotic. But when reading quotes from the study participants, the narrator would switch into accents including a Texan man's drawl, the giggle of a young girl, and an African American woman's emphatic attitude. And yes, it's just as cringe-worthy as you're imagining.

Title: The Sociopath Next Door
Author: Martha Stout
My Review:
I expect this book accomplished its intended purpose--that is, to raise awareness about the existence of sociopaths and to prepare the innocent to recognize and defend against them. But I already know that sociopaths exist and I'd been hoping for a more in-depth study of the topic. In that, this book was a disappointment.

From what I can tell, the majority of the author's education on the topic of sociopaths comes from counseling the people who have been traumatized by them. While this may serve as excellent fodder for cautionary tales, it gives a decidedly skewed perspective on the topic. She spends most of her time demonizing sociopaths and the rest of it uncritically glorifying the concept of a conscience. Which is awfully silly since sociopaths can be plenty monstrous all on their own without the sensationalism and the value of a conscience is widely recognized as pretty damned important.

Title: Twitter and Tear Gas: The Power and Fragility of Networked Protest
Author: Zeynep Tufekci
My Review:
"Technology is neither good nor bad; nor is it neutral" --Melvin Kranzberg

As the title suggests, this book is a study of protest and activism in the rise of social media. Zeynep compares modern activism to historical civil rights movements, interspersed with riveting accounts from her personal experiences within these communities.

While that would have been a fascinating and engaging account on its own, in the course laying the foundation for that narrow topic, the scope of the areas covered becomes an anthropological study of technology on social behavior that is both highly relevant to trajectory of current political and social events and deeply meaningful to me personally.

Throughout her work, Zeynup often points out the effect that technology has on human behaviors well understood by sociologists such as collective effervescence (in which individuals get swept up in a social movement) and homophily (the tendency of people to be drawn to people like themselves) and goes on to explain how those behaviors are amplified or modified by various technologies.

She discusses in great detail the effect that ad driven revenue has had on the algorithms in various social media platforms on cultural awareness and attitudes, as well as the tremendous power that these platforms wield.

She does an in-depth review of various platforms and examines how the choice and enforcement of specific policies such as identity and reputation can have certain emergent effects, both positive and negative. A real-name policy, for example, may make it easy for governments to identify and target political dissidents; while at the same time making it more difficult to anonymously harass persecuted minorities.

She does an analysis of the approaches that various governments have taken to navigate and control information with technology to retain power. For example, China's well known "great firewall" of selective censorship, focuses not on criticism, but rather any call to organize and mobilize. Turkey and Russia on the other hand have taken a different tactic--strategic campaigns to delegitimize social media as a source of news, in part by employing large groups to flood social media with posts intended to distract and spread doubt.

Well written, insightful, balanced, and smart--I'd highly recommend this book to anyone interested in activism, human behavior, technology, politics, or any combination of the above.

Title: Leaving Time
Author: Jodi Picoult
My Review:
This book was full of surprises, had a pretty big impact on me, and was nonetheless quite bad.

The coolest part by far is the fact that it takes place on an elephant sanctuary that is based on a real elephant sanctuary in Tennessee, and in fact many of the elephants in the book are based on real elephants from the sanctuary. This aspect of the book seems to have been very well researched and got me fascinated with elephants, inspiring me to pick up a number of other elephant related books.

As for the rest... for most of the book much of the character motivations and behavior made no sense, and the plot didn't seem to be going anywhere. It turns out that many of these flaws were in support of the twist ending. I respect what the author was trying to accomplish, and there was some satisfaction in how it came together. But even the twist ending was somewhat lacking, and did not justify the rest of the book.

Author: Jack Campbell
My Review:
I picked up this series because MacLoed Andrews is the narrator. If it weren't for his narration, I would have given up on this book a hundred pages in or so and certainly not continued with the series.

There are some really cool things about the world and the magic systems, the steampunk trappings and lots of adventure. Unfortunately, the main characters are downright terrible.

The series centers around the romance between Mari of the Mechanics Guild and Alain of the opposing Magicians guild as the young lovers grapple with the juxtaposition of their two worlds. One aspect of this comes about because the magicians are ruthlessly trained to suppress all emotion, while the mechanics are, well, not.

The dynamic that this produces is a nauseating interplay of the dramatic and emotional girl and the dumb and insensitive guy. Mari spends all of her time in self-absorbed hemming and hawing about her feelings and berating Alain for not reading her mind. Alain is cringingly clueless and so does whatever Mari tells him. Aside from promoting an offensive sexist stereotype, it made for a tiresome slog.

Title: Iorich (Vlad Taltos, #12)
Author: Steven Brust
My Review:
Vlad the assassin gets involved with politics and law--hilarity ensues.

Vlad is many years into life on the run when this tale begins. His resources are limited, he's estranged from his family, and of course, being hunted by assassins. So, when he hears that a friend, one of the most powerful people in the empire, has been unjustly charged with a crime for which the penalty is death, he returns to the heart of the empire to help. Through a combination of determination, audacity, and nothing to lose, he can accomplish things that all of his powerful friends can't.

I find the stories from this time in Vlad's life sad. He gets beat up a lot, and can't do much about it. He faces powers much greater than himself, and he loses a lot. When he prevails, it is not a hero's victory where all of his problems are fortuitously resolved by coincidence. Nor is it the hero martyr--where he struggles on to fight the good fight, sacrificing his own happiness because it's the Right Thing. Rather, his plans fall short, his victories are unsatisfying, and he walks away from a mostly thankless resolution and onto a life of continued struggle.

I respect the honesty of it.

Title: Jhegaala (Vlad Taltos, #11)

Title: Dzur (Vlad Taltos, #10)
Author: Steven Brust
My Review:
I begin to think that Brust uses the books in his Taltos series to experiment in writing styles.

In this story, the still hunted (but not yet worn down by the despair of being on the run) Vlad returns to the heart of the empire that is after him, to save his ex-wife, about which she is none too pleased. The now familiar theme in which Vlad puts himself into harms way for the sake of someone he cares about, and who would much rather he stay out of their business, unfolds in the typical fashion.

The delightful writing experiment that adds an element of flavor to the story is that each segment begins with an interlude of Vlad's experiencing one of the courses of his favorite meal. I have never read a foodie's joy, satisfaction, and contentment expressed so well. And woven into the descriptions are subtle philosophical points, foreshadowing, introspection and a sprinkling of wit.

If you're looking for a typical swashbuckling adventure story, you'll probably be put off by the foodie bits. But if you can get over your expectations for a minute, there's a lot to appreciate there.

Title: I Thought It Was Just Me (but it isn't): Telling the Truth About Perfectionism, Inadequacy, and Power
Author: BrenÃ© Brown
My Review:
I picked this up after reading and very much enjoying two of Brown's other books, Daring Greatly and The Gifts of Imperfection. I was specifically interested learning more about her work on shame resilience which is touched on in the other books.

If I'm not mistaken, this her first book--or at least the first of the three that I've read. It shows, both in her writing skills and in the development of her theories over time.

This book just didn't resonate with me. I really wish that it had been focused on shame and shame resiliency from a standpoint that would be applicable to everyone. Instead, her research focuses on women and spends a great deal of time on the social and cultural shame triggers. While these insights may be valuable for many women, it seems I'm in a very different demographic than the women who she interviewed. Expectations steaming from places like fashion magazines, societal pressure to have children and subsequently be a good parent, and the pressure to being a good wife and Christian just aren't my deal.

There were a few valuable nuggets in here. And it is enlightening to understand the conflicting expectations that many women navigate. But boy, I sure was happy to come to the end of this one.

My Review:
I've been drawn to mindfulness for some time, but there are few resources for those who are interested in the pragmatic and scientifically proven benefits of mindfulness without integrating some form of dogma and mysticism.

Leave it to Google to tackle this problem.

Written by an engineer and oriented towards an skeptical, results-oriented audience, Search Inside Yourself strips away any particular belief systems related to mindfulness practice and emotional intelligence, explaining it in plain English.(*) The scientific studies demonstrating the benefits of mindfulness are presented, as well as providing the fundamentals of physiology and neurology upon which the results of mindfulness practice can be understood. I found it particularly insightful when Meng quotes some ancient text, often something baffling that I had encountered before, and translates it in terms that make sense to a modern audience.

The second half of the book is solid, but more oriented towards interpersonal relationships, particularly geared towards the workplace. It's a great overview of a school of thought around the importance of values, culture, a growth oriented mentality, and good management. Many sources are referenced that will be familiar to people who are passionate about this sort of thing, including [b:The Five Dysfunctions of a Team: A Leadership Fable|21343|The Five Dysfunctions of a Team A Leadership Fable|Patrick Lencioni|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1400841022s/21343.jpg|22516], [b:Good to Great: Why Some Companies Make the Leap...And Others Don't|76865|Good to Great Why Some Companies Make the Leap... and Others Don't|James C. Collins|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1388177779s/76865.jpg|1094028], and [b:Delivering Happiness: A Path to Profits, Passion, and Purpose|6828896|Delivering Happiness A Path to Profits, Passion, and Purpose|Tony Hsieh|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1344267716s/6828896.jpg|7039054] to name a few. An excellent summary for anyone not familiar with this way of thinking. For those who are, it's still worth a re-read, but most of the value will be in seeing these together in a cohesive whole, and learning a few related mindfulness/emotional intelligence exercises.

Recommended to anyone with the slightest interest in mindfulness from an evidence-based foundation. And if you like this, I would also recommend [b:Mindsight: The New Science of Personal Transformation|6315775|Mindsight The New Science of Personal Transformation|Daniel J. Siegel|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1320475978s/6315775.jpg|6501014].


* Caveat: This is particularly oriented towards engineers, so it is not clear to me that non-geeks would call analogies to image resolution "plain English."

More fluffy goth fiction continuing the story from [b:Daughter of Smoke & Bone|8490112|Daughter of Smoke & Bone (Daughter of Smoke & Bone #1)|Laini Taylor|http://d202m5krfqbpi5.cloudfront.net/books/1338613368s/8490112.jpg|13355552]. I found a lot of the themes redundant and dragged out. Yes, a demon and an angel are still in love. Yes, everyone feels guilty. Get on with it already. On the other hand, it got a lot darker, and the adventure plot was a fun ride. Rather irked that it ended on such a cliff-hanger though.

All and all, alright, but not nearly as well done goth pop candy as the first in the series.

Title: Ishmael: An Adventure of the Mind and Spirit (Ishmael, #1)
Author: Daniel Quinn
My Review:
This books starts with the assumption that the world needs saving. For someone who agrees with this right out the gate, I can see how the book might be powerful. I don't happen to believe that, and without some supporting evidence of such, I couldn't really get into it.

On the other hand, it did change the way I think about the world. I doubt it was in the way that the author intended, but that is nevertheless high praise in my book.

Title: Thirteen
Author: Richard K. Morgan
My Review:
I was so excited to get the new Morgan book that I went as far as to buy it hardcover -- something I rarely do with fiction books. Maybe my expectations were too high, but I was quite disappointed. Sure, there were the kind of cool technologies and neat ideas that get sci-fi geeks like me going. There was even plenty of Richard Morgan's signature visceral grit and sex and violence. Nevertheless, I found myself not excited about picking it up again, and glad when I was finally done with it.

I am probably judging this book unfairly. If it were by some unknown author that I just happened to pick up off the shelf, I would give it three stars -- it is solid science fiction. But c'mon Morgan. I know you can do better than that.

Author: George R.R. Martin

Author: Ursula Vernon

Author: Connie Willis

Author: James A. Owen
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers

Title: Anita
Author: Keith Roberts
My Review: A collection of short stories from the life of a teenage witch and her cookey grandmother. Fun fluff. But I discovered I didn't much like Anita.

Title: Ruby Red (Precious Stone Trilogy, #1)
Author: Kerstin Gier
My Review: Meh. YA scifi about British time traveling teenagers. Not particularly well done.

Title: Fairest (The Lunar Chronicles, #3.5)
Author: Marissa Meyer
My Review: I do so love the Lunar Chronicles, and I enjoyed the villain backstory. Even so, this isn't quite up to par with the rest of the series.

Title: The Wishing Spell (The Land of Stories, #1)
Author: Chris Colfer
My Review: Meh. A mediocre parody of The Chronicles of Narnia.

Title: Delirium (Delirium, #1)
Author: Lauren Oliver
My Review: Interesting YA scifi. (Why does so much YA revolve around people's emotions being shut down in some way? You'd think by the quantity of parables that seem to spread the message that Feelings Are Important that emotional shutdown is some kind of epidemic.) I enjoyed it well enough, but probably won't pick up any more of the series.

Title: The Spiritglass Charade (Stoker & Holmes, #2)
Author: Colleen Gleason
My Review: I like plenty of YA, but I didn't find this one compelling. It all struck me as silly and simplistic.

Title: All Our Yesterdays
Author: Cristin Terrill
My Review: A dark and gritty young adult time travel story.  I loved the juxtaposition of privileged teenage angsty love against the grim life on the run with self-sacrifice to save the world.  Throw in plenty of time-travel complexity and you get a great mind-bending, YA adventure.

Title: Dreams of Gods & Monsters (Daughter of Smoke & Bone, #3)
Author: Laini Taylor
My Review:
I was really impressed by how well the story kept together into the final book of the trilogy, and was of consistent quality throughout. I was also surprised by how eager I was to read this when it came out last month. I guess I've grown rather fond of Karou, Akiva and Zuzana.

I'll admit, the epic hand wringing taking pages to describe each characters reaction to every second did start to wear thin. But it's YA--what do you expect?

I was also a bit disappointed by the ending... the last few chapters introduced a whole new storyline, then rushed to wrap it up.


Overall though, a good and satisfying ending to a fun series.

Title: Daughter of Smoke & Bone (Daughter of Smoke & Bone, #1)
Author: Laini Taylor
Publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
My Review: Fluffy goth fantasy about a mysterious, tattooed, blue haired girl who divides her time between her art studies in Prauge and the realm of magic, demons and angels.  This teenage saga hits all the high points: romance, improbably hot demons, rebellion, angst, loss of innocence.  If it's literary candy you're looking for, this will leave you satisfied.

Title: The Ring of Solomon (Bartimaeus, #0.5)
Author: Jonathan Stroud
My Review:
Another great Bartimaeus story--a fantasy adventure on the darker side, peppered with sardonic wit. The characters are well developed with complex motivations that muddy even the templates of hero and anti-hero. This is typical of the series, but I thinks this book is the best execution of that aspect so far.

I was happy to see that this novel departed from the Nathaniel storyline, and instead told one of the tales that Bartimaeus frequently brags about. Nathaniel's story was finished, and a change of setting and introduction of new characters did the series good.

There were a number of times in this book when I found myself laughing out loud, or when I would have highlighted a particularly clever passage if I'd been reading in a non-audio format.

Title: The Golem's Eye (Bartimaeus, #2)
Author: Jonathan Stroud
Publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
My Review:
All of the things I loved about the first book were present in this one as well--complex characters, a great story, mechanisms of magic that made an aesthetically pleasing and effective device, and a dry sense of humor.

This book got considerably darker than the first. Bad things happen to good people, and good people do bad things. In one scene, I found myself legitimately afraid.

I'm quite looking forward to the final book in the series.

Title: The City of Gold and Lead
Author: John Christopher
My Review: I really enjoyed re-reading the first book in the series.  For some reason, this one I felt more like I was slogging through a boring kids book that I had already read.  Not sure if I'll finish the series.

Title: The Last of the Winnebagos
Author: Connie Willis
My Review: For such a short and slow-paced novella, there's a lot going on here.  Left me thinking about a lot of things.  Worth the read.

Title: Blackout (All Clear, #1)
Author: Connie Willis
My Review:
This is a book about worrying.

Ok, so yes--it's actually another story by Connie Willis about her world of British time traveling historians in which, in spite of the laws of time travel and the mechanisms of the net which ensure that both the continuum and its travelers are safe, somehow our hapless historians seem to find themselves in increasingly improbable exceptions to the rule, and hilarity ensues. This one is set in WWII, and is a fascinating depiction of the day-to-day lives of Londoners as they endured raids, measles, and evacuations, and treatment in army hospitals.

But really, at its core, it is a book about worrying.

For every event or piece of dialogue that takes place, one of our three main characters expounds on an internal monologue of at least five times the length, spiraling over every possible risk, fretting over every action or word spoken, fuming in self-doubt and regret, and then proceeding to tell one another that they "musn't worry about that".

It stressed me the fuck out.

In the last 30% of the book, I was far too invested in the characters to stop reading. But I was so looking forward to being done with it, so all the worrying would be over with one way or the other.

And then finally, after all the stress and waiting, I reached the final words of the book: "The riveting story begun in Blackout concludes in Connie Willis's All Clear."


Fuck this book. Do not read it.

Title: Hard Magic (Grimnoir Chronicles, #1)
Author: Larry Correia
My Review: I loved this book.  It's a fun adventure story, set in the hard-boiled alternate history of the 1930's.  In addition to tommy-guns, dames, and organized crime, there are also "actives" who use their superpowers in their respective mob related, secret society, or national superpower capacities as each sees fit.  Just about every single one of the characters was a delight, even the evil antagonists.  The audio was particularly well done.

Title: Wings of Wrath (The Magister Trilogy, #2)
Author: C.S. Friedman
My Review: This book was perfectly good. Lots to like about it. But somehow, nothing I loved.

Title: In Conquest Born (In Conquest Born, #1)
Author: C.S. Friedman
My Review:
In this story set spanning galaxies, C. S. Friedman presents us with two distinct racial cultures, each with a complex culture and value system, at war with one another. We watch her two main characters start from nothing and forge their respective personalities and build their power. Meanwhile, the political machinations of the three powers of the age--the Braxana, the Azeans, and the Institute--both broil internally and thrash against one another. Not only do her individual characters develop, but so does the attitudes of the societies across galaxies.

Action packed, and epic story arc, and emotional depth all at once. Great scifi.

Title: Redshirts
Author: John Scalzi
My Review:
A parody of the Star Trek world, told from the perspective of the hapless "Redshirts", those ill-fated extras fated to die sudden and improbable deaths. The preface had me laughing until my belly ached, and I thought it was going to be a collection of such short stories. In reality, it continued on to follow a series of characters through an adventure that danced all over the fourth wall. While that too was so funny it had my eyes tearing up, it took the joke much too far. By the end, it seemed as though the book was attempting to implement the very poor writing styles it had just lampooned.

For avid star trek fans who have sense of humor, I would still recommend it--though giving up about halfway through might be wise.

Title: Dominion (The Coldfire Trilogy, #0.5)
Author: C.S. Friedman
My Review: A novelette prequel to the Coldfire Trilogy that I love so much.  I was suprised to find that it was written after the the three novels of the trilogy, as it lacked a lot of the polish and depth that made those books so charming.  Even so, it was a fun little romp with the Terrant character.

Title: This Immortal
Author: Roger Zelazny
My Review: Couldn't get into this.  A languid pace combining mythological gods with scifi... I don't have the attention span for that right now.

Title: A Fire Upon the Deep (Zones of Thought, #1)
Author: Vernor Vinge
My Review:
When you encounter aliens in scifi, they're rarely all that alien. Sure, they've got testicles and the wrong number of eyes and mouths. But basically they act like humans, and interact with humans like humans.

I love that the aliens in this book are alien in ways that fundamentally change how they think, behave, and each species understands one another.

There's a lot more going on in this book, but that's my favorite part.

Title: The Steel Remains (A Land Fit for Heroes, #1)
Author: Richard K. Morgan
My Review:
This is perhaps the only fantasy book I would consider to be in the same genre as the [b:A Game of Thrones|13496|A Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire, #1)|George R.R. Martin|https://d202m5krfqbpi5.cloudfront.net/books/1369520317s/13496.jpg|1466917] series. Dark, violent, graphic, abrasive characters with complex motivations. Some of the supernatural, but it feels incidental. And it makes perfect sense that this would be [a:Richard K Morgan|7247535|Richard K Morgan|https://www.goodreads.com/assets/nophoto/user/u_50x66-d9f6a4a5badfda0f69e70cc94d962125.png]'s first work of fantasy.

I'm looking forward to reading the next book in the series.

Title: Way Station
Author: Clifford D. Simak
My Review: I'm inclined to call this contemplative scifi. A very slow pace, using some nifty scifi trappings to pontificate on the nature of existence, the meaning of life, that sort of thing. It was entertaining to listen to on the flight home, but the end fell a bit flat for me.

Title: Dragon (Vlad Taltos, #8)
Author: Steven Brust
My Review: Our favorite assassin finds himself as a foot-soldier--hilarity ensues.  To my naive perspective, it seemed like the descriptions of life as a soldier were educational and accurate than I would have expected.  Other than that, rakish Vlad and his smart-ass familiar Loiosh were as entertaining as always.

Title: Reamde
Author: Neal Stephenson
My Review:
I have not read such an intelligent action novel in quite some time. Moreover, I don't know that I have ever read an adventure oriented story at this caliber of intellectual engagement that wasn't scifi.

Not since [a:Richard K. Morgan|16496|Richard K. Morgan|http://d.gr-assets.com/authors/1175224722p2/16496.jpg] Kovacs series has a book felt so much like watching an action flick. Because of this, I kept being surprised when the characters made well considered and sensibly motivated actions. And boy was it nice to have a cast of believably smart characters. Unlike the Hollywood demonstration of a geek, in which nonsensical technical terms are bandied about to convey to the audience that you are meeting the Computer Geek Character, the smarts and skills of these characters were demonstrated through applications that make sense in the real world.

Of course this meant frequently delving into lengthy and detailed explanations on various topics--the world of MMORPGs, what it's like to found and run a company, how computer viruses can be transmitted, the world of off-the-grid survivalist lifestyle, the operation and strengths and weaknesses of a vast array of firearms... the list goes on. There were some moments when I found one or two of the expositions tedious, but worth it overall.

Neal Stephenson is one of my favorite authors, and I had saved reading this one for quite some time, wanting to choose the moment when I could really savor it. It was worth the wait. The action and adventure kept me on the edge of my seat, and the intellectual challenge made me work to keep up. I was well and thoroughly engrossed, which came at perfect timing.

Title: Mirror Dance (Vorkosigan Saga, #8)
Author: Lois McMaster Bujold
My Review:
Engaging scifi adventure with lots of psychological thriller elements. It tackles, the perhaps well worn but always fun, topics of identity and ethics with regards to cloning, but with with plenty of twists to make it stand on its own merit.

Bujould's typical mastery of character development, emotional depth, and a writing style in which interpersonal relationship are intrinsic to the plot development makes what would otherwise be a perfectly fine spaceship shoot-em-up political drama to a new level.

Also plenty of violence and horror, so the feint of heart beware.

Title: His Majesty's Dragon (Temeraire, #1)
Author: Naomi Novik
My Review: A fantasy series about dragons and the special relationship they have with their human companions is hardly unique.  Except in this series, the human companion in question is a middle-aged, cantankerous, and stodgy British navy captain with a strong sense of duty and honor.  In this fantasy based in history, the dragons are vessels of war--not unlike a navy ship, each dragon has a captain, a crew, and an arsenal of guns and cannons.  These divergences change the flavor sufficiently to make the stories both amusing and engaging.

Title: Bellwether
Author: Connie Willis
My Review: The story of a scientist working at a large corporation serves as a mechanism for social commentary, sprinkled with little tidbits of fads throughout history.  The lampooning of corporate culture and fads of all stripes is amusing, and the characters are well developed. Not my favorite Connie Willis piece by a long shot, but entertaining.

Title: The Forever War (The Forever War #1)
Author: Joe Haldeman
My Review: I know this is one of the classics, but I just couldn't get into it.  The main character faced a constant stream of misery against a background of futility.  There were some redeeming qualities, but not enough.

Title: Sailing to Byzantium
Author: Robert Silverberg
My Review:
An entertaining scifi novelette with existential themes. Just about the perfect length for the story--it takes some time to puzzle out the world, throws you a quick twist, then wraps up nicely. Recommended if you're looking for something more substantive than a podcast but not ready to dive into a whole book.

Note: This review is for the single short story "Sailing to Byzantium", not the entire collection included in this listing.

Title: Beggars in Spain (Sleepless, #1)
Author: Nancy Kress
My Review:
Like Atlas Shrugged, this is a story for the purpose of exploring philosophical ideas. It attempts to reconcile the ideals if individual excellence and community. If we build a society that rewards individual effort, that creates inequality--"beggars" who have nothing to contribute. Should those people be rewarded for their mere existence? Can we treat them with compassion? How do we deal with the hatred of the have-nots to the haves, which seems to take place anytime there is inequality, regardless of how the have-nots are treated?

I appreciate the questions being raised, but if there was an answer woven somewhere throughout the storyline, it was unsatisfying at best. Many characters sought to address these problems in their own way, and each ultimately failed.

As a story, the writing was mediocre. As scifi, there was some neat geekery. As a philosophy, it left much to be desired. Still, I'm glad to have read it.

Title: Blood Music
Author: Greg Bear
My Review:
An epic hard scifi story that also had well developed characters. I was engaged throughout by the story, the science and the characters. And without getting too spoilery, the element of a change so rapid, pervasive, and core to the things we know to be true was quite thought provoking given its relevance to the pace of change in modern technology.

My only complaint is that the end didn't work for me--though that might be a matter of personal taste.

Title: The Persistence of Vision
Author: John Varley
My Review:
This engaging novelette explores a community of dumb and blind individuals designed and created by its inhabitants. I enjoyed the ideas about how the community could be not only functional, but in fact efficient and in some ways superior to the sighted, hearing mechanisms for cohabitation. I also found the element of using touch to read emotion and communicate compelling, as it is an interesting take on what I know of body language.

It got a little bit over-the-top with the hippy free love and spirituality aspect at times. Overall though, it was a fun thought experiment.

Title: Kraken
Author: China MiÃ©ville
My Review:
The usual Mieville themes were present: cities, violence, monsters, steampunk horror. He does these things well.

Overall though, I felt the execution of this book fell short of Mieville's other works. The use of abstractions and metaphor as major characters (ie memory, or the City of London) just didn't work for me. The mechanics of the universe felt very hand-wavey.

The plot was overly complex and sprawling. It was confusing to keep track of the number of groups, characters, interests, and even variety of beings. I'm all for the intellectual challenge of complexity that ties together artfully, but in this case it just resulted in me having less room to care about each element of the story.

For all of that, I basically enjoyed it. The dark and moody London, the exploration of religion and faith, the little bits of fantasy that sprinkled the world, the well defined characters--it's worth reading if you're a fan, just set your expectations to low.

Title: A Shadow in Summer (Long Price Quartet, #1)
Author: Daniel Abraham
My Review:
This was a decent story with well developed characters with complex motivations. The setting and Asian influenced culture was by far the most enjoyable--the robes of various occasions that the characters were constantly fussing with, the bowls of tea or wine that made excellent props that a character might consider during a serious conversation, and of course, the poses that were a key part of communication.

Overall, a decent read. It did take me quite awhile to get into, and I was disappointed by the ending. It left several questions unanswered, and had me wondering what the point of it all had been. If not for the latter, I'd have given it 3 stars.

Title: The Prestige
Author: Christopher Priest
My Review:
This dark story is told from the perspective of two feuding stage magicians in the early 1900's. A non-linear mystery on the topics of illusion, mentalism and deception, it is self-referential in its twists and turns, reveals and misdirection. It's spooky, set in an age where the distinction between science and magic was still fuzzy. It's moody, with themes of rivalry, revenge and regret.

I picked this up after seeing the film adaptation by Christopher Nolan, which is one of my favorite movies. I was pleased to discover that the spirit of the film was present in the book as well, but unfolded sufficiently differently to retain a sense of suspense. There is also a whole additional storyline not present in the movie, which made it more than just reading the same story in a different format.

Recommended if you like mysteries, or have even a passing interest in illusion and deception.

Title: Embassytown
Author: China MiÃ©ville
My Review:
This seemed a departure from Mieville's typical style. The world was a bit less vivid, and quite a bit less dirty and violent than Perdido Street Station or The Scar. Also surprising was the theme of linguistic geekery and the lengthy sections of philosophical pontification.

I enjoyed it, though not quite as well as the others of his that I've read.

Title: Shadows in Flight (The Shadow Series, #5)
Author: Orson Scott Card
My Review:
Overall, I enjoyed this story. Bean's children were fun to get to know, and the juxtaposition of their brutal intelligence against their innocence and naivety was a thought provoking area to explore.

I was sad though to discover that I'm no longer as enamored with the Enderverse as I once was. Unlike the other books in the series, this felt very sequeley--characters and events of the first book playing a major role in this story, in spite of being lifetimes later and lightyears away.


I was also disappointed with the development that the drones do in fact have independent minds, the queens are actually oppressive and cruel tyrants, and that Ender's hive queen deliberately deceived him on this point. This is a major change to the Enderverse cannon, which could have been justified if executed well, and if it added substantially to the collection of works. However, the only clear purpose it served was as a trivial plot device to give the children a reason to usurp their father. Other than that, it could have been removed entirely without changing much about the story.

On the other hand, the introduction of the rabs, the kings, and their respective relationships to the queen added a novel dimension to the Formic (bugger) species. In some ways, the story of the kings stole the spotlight from Bean and his family--it was alien, beautiful, and tragic. And unlike most of the other content, it was in no way rehashing content from past book, but served to expand the world.

Title: Red Mars (Mars Trilogy, #1)
Author: Kim Stanley Robinson
My Review: A hard scifi book, with a story line covering hundreds of years and a number of eras and major events involving the colonization of mars.  It is impressive that, considering the level of technical depth in the geeky bits, the plot lines centered around the characters were equally well developed.

Title: The Native Star (Veneficas Americana, #1)
Author: M.K. Hobson
My Review: This vaguely steampunk, mostly magic fantasy book just didn't grab me.  The main character struck me immediately as a silly girl, and I predicted the ostensibly unlikely fellow she would come to fall in love with in the first chapter.  After getting fairly well into the book, I ended up listening to a chunk of this when I was ill and dosing in and out of consciousness, and wasn't too disappointed that I missed huge swaths when I next picked it up.  It's not entirely fair to say I abandoned it--I have only 12 minutes left.  But I have no particular desire to listen to them.

Title: Guilty Pleasures (Anita Blake, Vampire Hunter, #1)
Author: Laurell K. Hamilton
My Review:
For a trashy vampire novel, this book was... wow, so trashy!

Our hero is a sexy supernatural detective with special powers that make her just powerful enough to have an advantage over her post-human foes, but not powerful enough to keep her from getting into trouble when the plot requires it. In just the first few chapters, she has already accidentally visited a vampire strip show, interrogated a zombie, and narrowly escaped attempted rape by a giant wererat. Yes, you read that right--a giant wererat.

I was almost tempted to finish it to see just what new heights of over-the-top trashiness it reached, but the disjointed and nonsensical plot was pretty unbearable.

Title: Enchantment
Author: Orson Scott Card
My Review:
I enjoyed this story. A Russian fairy tale, it exposed me to a lot of interesting things about Russian and Jewish culture, as well as some neat stuff about language. I really enjoyed the aesthetic of the magic, and the very distinct personalities of the characters.

It did go a bit slow at times and, and there was some social and political commentary that I could have done without.

The narration was superb--the accents were very well done, and the characters were easily identifiable from the voice acting.

Title: Citizen of the Galaxy
Author: Robert A. Heinlein
My Review:
I found this book so engrossing that I listened to it for hours at home on the weekend, rather than just in the car during my commute. As each layer of the story unfolds, you realize that the story that you had just settled into was only the beginning of a much grander plot, a bigger universe. Even so, each era in the progression of the story is full of detail and depth.

I liked the last part of the story the least, and began to find the wide-eyed innocence of the main character tiresome. The ending was a bit weak. All in all though, a great story.

Title: Earthborn (Homecoming, #5)
Author: Orson Scott Card
My Review: I'm ambivalent about this one.  Good story-telling, but the religious overtones are laid on thick and they become quite tiresome.

Title: Roadmarks
Author: Roger Zelazny
My Review:
I knew when I opened to the first page and the chapter heading said "Two" that something unusual was in store. It grabs at your curiosity right off, forcing you to puzzle out the world as you go. For the first third of the book I was utterly mystified, and it seemed implausible that it would ever make a whit of sense. By the second third I was beginning to catch on. And to my great surprise, by the end it had resolved into a sensible, satisfying and whimsical story.

For such a short story, it was packed with delightful pieces of the world, side-plots, technologies and characters. At one point, I said "wow" out-loud. Recommended.

Title: Rainbows End
Author: Vernor Vinge
My Review:
A story of a once brilliant and skilled, now especially curmudgeonly and mean old man having to face the alienness that time has wrought upon his world. A natural stage of life, except in this case his Alzheimer's cured 30 years later makes the transition rather abrupt. Not only does Robert Gu need to adapt to the new world, but he also must rediscover who he is and who he wants to be.

This book isn't really about awesome new tech, and it won't satisfy your cyberpunk itch. The main character isn't likable, nor are many of the other characters. However, he is an interesting character, and this is a character driven story.

I'm glad I read it, but it wasn't very fun.

Title: Rollback
Author: Robert J. Sawyer
My Review:
This is a rare occasion where I feel comfortable saying unequivocally: This book was pretty much terrible.

The characters were unlikable, the dialog was flat with frequent bouts of rambling exposition, and the story referenced current and recent events with a depth and frequency that made it feel dated a scant six years after publication.

The theme of aging had a lot of promise, and the lengthy and detailed descriptions of life for the characters of 80+ years seemed like it had the potential to be a powerful, if unpleasant, topic to explore. Perhaps it could have been if the overall execution hadn't been so poor.

Title: The Time Traveler's Wife
Author: Audrey Niffenegger
My Review:
This book is a love story.

Henry has a genetic disorder that causes him to be involuntarily thrust into the past or future, arriving naked, and staying for hours, minutes or days before being pulled back to the present. His relationship with his eventual wife, Claire, is shaped by the the quirks and hardships of his condition, from their asynchronous meeting in time, to the life that they share together.

It is sweet and sad, the main characters being almost entirely defined by their love for one another. (At times, to an almost groan-worthy extreme, but not often.) It is poetic, both in the language of the book itself, and the love that the characters have for art, literature, language, music and poetry.

I imagine that many scifi fans looking for the excitement of spaceships and time machines will be disappointed by the slow paced, touchy-feely nature of this book. Henry is not trying to save the world or repair the space-time continuum--he's just a guy, wanting nothing more than to live a normal life. But if you're in the mood for a love story, this is a compelling tale.

Title: The City & the City
Author: China MiÃ©ville
My Review:
A decent mystery novel revolving around the mind-bending mechanics of two metaphysically overlapping cities. The hard boiled detective, the up-and-coming female beat cop, the gruff old timer prone to overuse of force; these were all perhaps over-used tropes, but enjoyable execution of them nonetheless. As to the social implications of the two cities intersecting, and the complex maneuvering required of its respective citizens... it was engaging to a point. Increasingly though, it came across as needlessly complicated. And truth be told it was never clear to me that the overlap was in fact metaphysical, let alone how and why it came to be. Given that the interplay between the city and the city was the premise upon which the rest of the story was built, the insufficient setup was a real failing.

Standing on its own, and if speculative fiction murder mysteries are your thing, it's a respectable showing of that category. Compared to the other works by the same author though, it leaves much to be desired.

Title: Dying of the Light
Author: George R.R. Martin
My Review: While this story is set against a scifi backdrop, it is much more a story of culture clash, of progress versus tradition, and of identity. Even with all of the complex philosophical overtones, it doesn't skimp on action.  Excellent book.

Title: Dreamsongs, Volume I
Author: George R.R. Martin
My Review:
I don't usually read short story collections, but picked this one up by way of A Song of Fire and Ice--like many of his fans, I'd run out of books in the series and wanted more.

This collection left me with a strong impression of Martin's writing style, with themes that I now recognize in the Song series. Even in his earliest and least mature work, he is still a gifted story teller with a talent for weaving words together beautifully. His worlds are vivid, his characters distinct and compelling, and his tales are drenched in mood.

By far though the most consistent attribute of all of his work is that his stories are always dark. At times tragic and beautiful, profoundly lonely and mad, sweetly sorrowful, brutal and cruel and at times even wandering into the repulsive, they are all at their core dark, dark, dark.

Title: The Multiplex Man
Author: James P. Hogan
My Review:
This book was... not good. I first realized this when I read the steamy sex scene expressed as, "They kissed and fondled for awhile." Even though this was pretty early on, for some reason I tried to stick it out. Sure, the writing is amateurish, I figured. But it's a decent scifi adventure story, right?

Wrong. The plot drags along at a pace that you could still keep up with half-asleep. (I should know, I was for much of it.) The libertarian agenda is laid on so thick it's enough to make you gag--even if you like the agenda.

The best I can say about it is that it's pretty amusing in an unintentional sort of way. The last time I picked it up (a month ago at least) I laughed out loud when the main character mused to himself, "I guess lucky coincidences aren't just for cheesy action heroes!"

Title: The Unit
Author: Ninni Holmqvist
My Review:
The Unit depicts a future world constructed for the purpose of communicating a political and social statement. Like other works of fiction fitting that description, the storytelling is secondary to the propaganda, and so judged as a story it falls somewhere between decent and mediocre.

If, on the other hand, it is judged by its ability to emotionally connect the reader to the views being expressed, it ranks among the best of its kind, putting it alongside Atlas Shrugged, 1984, and Market Forces(*). It fabricates a near-future society in which a set of commonly held current day values are taken to their logical extreme. The depiction is both believable and horrific, challenging worldview assumptions that readers may normally take for granted.

Even as just a story, I found it compelling. If nothing else, it has the novelty of being a scifi story being told from the perspective of a middle-aged woman. The characters were well developed and changed over the course of the novel, the plot was well paced, and it had a solid ending. There are tedious and slow bits, and at times it felt contrived and predictable. But overall I found myself looking forward to returning to it everyday.




(*) Market Forces stands out among these as a truly superb story, even when separated from its message.



After reading some other reviews, I found myself wanting to explore the social themes represented in the book.



At its core, The Unit speaks to how society values people. Now, it's worth noting here that the society in question is, I believe, Sweeden. So, this was a bit puzzling at times as an American reader.

In the story, "dispensable" people are rounded up in middle-age, and brought to live together in a community. On one hand, this community is a picturesque facility, providing all of the luxury, social connections, and creative fodder for the ideal retirement. This is in stark juxtaposition to the purpose of their admittance to The Unit--to serve as guinea pigs in medical experiments and organ donors to better serve the population of "needed" individuals.

At the heart of the story is the slow unfolding of what personalities and lifestyle choices result in an individual ending up as dispensable. People with children are needed, because additional humans contribute to the economic success of the "community". Likewise, gainfully employees individuals are economically valuable. People who have a romantic partner who are willing to register their love officially also become needed, though this somewhat breaks the economic pattern otherwise established.

This leaves independent, introverted, creative, and academic types being the most likely to end up as dispensable. They are less likely to hold down a steady job, let alone achieve career success, favoring instead to focus on their writing or music or art. They are the oddballs and value solitude and therefore have trouble finding a partner.

The cruel irony is that when this group of people is finally brought together after a lifetime of struggle and loneliness, they are suddenly among a group of people that can understand one another. They forge friendships, thrive creatively, find happiness, discover love.

But the lifespan of a individual in The Unit is short--a six year tenure is not unheard of, but quite rare. Moreover, this long sought-after life fulfillment is soured by the maladies inflicted on them as side effects of medical experiments, and the slow harvesting of their bodies. Half-deafness from a donated ear bone; boils from one drug treatment; madness from another.

While the members of The Unit express bitterness, rage and rebellion against the institution that put them here, at the same time they accurately represent a population that, at its core, holds the same values. This is demonstrated through their meek submission in being brought to The Unit, their cooperation in participating in the experiments, and their acquiesce in giving their fatal "final donation" of a major organ. Most of all, it is demonstrated by the ending of the book, in which Dorrit chooses not to flee and try to survive with her unexpected child, but instead gives it up and makes her final donation.

One could interpret these behaviors as stemming from perceived or actual helplessness to fight the system. However, I saw it as something more than that--in spite of their anger and defiant attitude, deep down they believed in the tenants of the society to which they belong: that they are dispensable, and that their purpose is to serve the greater good of The Community. This was a bold move by the author, showing the power that our deepest rooted value systems have on us, in spite of intellectual positions to the contrary.

In a second theme that runs in parallel, the community, in its pursuit of gender equality has criminalized anything hinting at differentiated gender roles. It starts with measures that some would find innocuous--legislated requirements that both parents share equally in both work and care of children. Then it follows that there should be no gender differentiation of work in the home--women must change their own tires, and men must do their own cooking. Finally, it becomes illegal for males to take a dominant role in courtship or in the bedroom.

This leaves a segment of the population for whom they have a dark secret--a taboo and illicit fetish for traditional hetero-normative gender roles.

I found this last theme fascinating as it is close to an area of some agitation for me--namely, the lack of distinction for many between gender equality and gender differentiation.

Title: Eifelheim
Author: Michael Flynn
My Review:
I couldn't get into the writing and presentation style, and I found the story unbelievable beyond the suspension of disbelief required of any fantasy/scifi tale.

It didn't help that the audio was weird and amateurish. (The narrator actually read the entire table of contents, which I endured since I was driving. And then proceeded to start in on the list of characters, for which I threw caution to the wind and fast-forwarded while driving.)

Early on, I decided to use this book as an experiment to test the hypothesis of, "If you have to ask 'Should I stop reading this book' the answer is yes." I need a broader sample set, but at 9 parts of 14, it seems a good data point in favor.

Title: The Pool of Fire
Author: John Christopher
My Review: I think my mistake was ordering all three books in the trilogy at the same time.  I then felt obligated to finish them all, even though I wasn't feeling it anymore after the second one.  Still didn't like the main character, still found the writing style overly simplistic, but the pace did pick up a bit in this one.

Title: Ghostwritten
Author: David Mitchell
My Review:
I'm rarely able to get into short story collections--I like to become immersed into a world, get to know a set of characters. There were two main elements that set Ghostwritten apart for me.

First was the subtle and often minor threads connecting the stories to one another. Even though the stories were most often completely unrelated to one another, this device evoked an entirely different effect. Rather than feeling as though with each new story I was starting over, instead it felt as though some new part of the same world was opening up to me.

Ok, so that's probably just my weird thing.

The far more compelling theme across all of the stories was the ability of the author to put you inside the head of his characters. Each story is narrated the first-person perspective of its protagonist, not an uncommon device to be sure. But usually the term seems to extend to their experiences, what they see, the conversations they have, the thoughts that go through their head.

Mitchell takes the notion of first-person perspective to a whole new level. You are so far into the worldview, belief-system, and self-image of the narrating character that you may come to the end of a story before realizing that they are quite mad. The experience of having a reality that you have, albeit only temporarily constructed, crumble beneath you is powerful and not entirely comfortable.

Of course, not all of the stories fuck with your head to that extreme. But for each you must struggle to discern the reality of the world through the imperfect perspective of the main character, not unlike from your own imperfect perception in this world.

Title: The Postman
Author: David Brin
My Review: An oddly heartwarming post-apocalyptic tale.  The writing style was so simplistic and straight-forward that I would almost associate it with young adult fiction, if not for the brutality and violence--which made for an unusual juxtaposition.  Overall, a quick read and I enjoyed it.

Title: The Dreaming Void (Void, #1)
Author: Peter F. Hamilton
My Review: Entertaining, not great.

Title: Little Brother (Little Brother, #1)
Author: Cory Doctorow
My Review:
This book is an anthropological study of San Francisco culture, a text book on current security and hacking technology, and a modern day 1984, and the movie Hackers all mushed together. As someone who has varying degrees of familiarity with just about every piece of technology or micro-culture presented in the book, I found it endlessly entertaining. It's like when you hear a song from an obscure band that you like featured in a pop-culture movie or tee vee show. There's a moment of almost giddy delight at seeing something you felt is yours alone put in the spotlight for the world to see what is so great about it. For geeks, hackers, gamers, hipsters and San Franciscians, it's that feeling a hundred times over.

And for anyone with libertarian values who is more than a little on edge about the direction of anti-terrorism policies in the US, the future it paints is deeply unsettling. In particular, the setting of real technologies, places and cultures from my life made the story all too plausible. I made the mistake of listening to the bit of this book where it goes from the normal life of a seventeen year old kid in San Francisco to an Orwellian horror story while waiting in line to get my photo taken at the DMV. I wouldn't normally describe the DMV as creepy, but that day it sure was.

All of that being said, I don't think that this book has the timeless artistic quality of a masterpiece. The deep spiral of in-jokes makes its appeal fairly narrow, and the constant references to all things modern will not help it age well. But it's a fun book--I'd recommend it to the people who are already into Cory Doctorow.

Title: The Gargoyle
Author: Andrew Davidson
My Review:
I admit, I almost stopped reading this book before making it through the first chapter. I was driving along the bay bridge when my wandering mind was jerked back to the graphic and deeply disturbing scene that was playing. I spent the remainder of my ride home cringing, flinching, and occasionally emitting small noises of shock and distress. When I got home, I immediately looked up the book on amazon to determine if it was fiction or non--if it was fiction, I figured, there was no reason to subject myself to such an upsetting story.

One of the reviews on amazon changed my mind. It acknowledged the graphic and unpleasant nature of the beginning of the book, but swore up and down it would be worth it, and pleaded with readers to stick with it.

I'm glad I did.

It is a beautifully written, highly allegorical novel with vivid images--sometimes beautiful and emotional, sometimes graphic and violent. There are themes of tragic romance, of religion and mysticism, of a passionate and driven madwoman, of a shockingly unsympathetic burn victim in a hospital bed. There are frequent divergences, like a cynical and bitter version of Bill Bryson, to delve into the science or history behind some small detail relevant to the story.

It's noteworthy that this is clearly written for a pop audience. Some readers used to popular novels may find it a challenge to keep up with the frequent changes in perspective. While some readers used to complex scifi or dense fantasy might find it somewhat simplistic. To both audiences I would suggest adjusting your expectations--this is something altogether different.

Title: The Algebraist
Author: Iain M. Banks
My Review:
I promised myself I would give this book at least 100 pages before I gave up on it. Boy was that a hard promise to keep.

I'm not saying the book was bad. It had a distinct thing, to be sure. The book reads a lot like an action movie, using common movie tropes I don't think I have ever seen in books. The kick the dog intro scene with the bad guy, to demonstrate /just/ how evil he is. The ostensibly witty banter between characters. Little details that give characters more history and depth, such as "The rest of them just wore standard outdoor/hiking gear, though naturally Sal's was subtly but noticeable superior and doubtlessly wildly more expensive."

If you had described that to me before reading the book, I would not have thought that it would be a bad thing. But in practice it came across as obvious and shallow.

The heft of the thing didn't help. Knowing that I had over 400 pages ahead of me of movie quality fluff to chew through made me procrastinate picking it up in the evenings that I had set aside for reading.

It was a long hundred pages, taking me a month to get through. Maybe it isn't bad, but it couldn't hold my attention.

Title: Fairyland
Author: Paul J. McAuley
My Review:
The dyspepsia world of Fairyland is vivid in its filth and brutality. The technology introduced makes for compelling mechanics, and they build upon and play off of one another.

Sound like a great (albeit, unpleasant) book? Well, it was for the first two thirds. The book was broken up into three independent stories. The switch from "book" one to two felt like it added a lot of depth to the world, and that the main character grew and changed a lot. By contrast, the switch from two to three felt frustrating that things still weren't resolved, and the main character seemed pathetic to still be on this quest.

The pace of my reading slowed to such a comical crawl towards the end. It took me weeks to force myself through the last five pages. I'm stunned, and more than a little bit relieved that it's finally done with.

Title: The Traveler (Fourth Realm, #1)
Author: John Twelve Hawks
My Review: Ugh.  Why didn't I give up on this book sooner?

Title: Dragonbreath (Dragonbreath, #1)
Author: Ursula Vernon
My Review: A fun kids adventure book featuring imaginative creatures, expressive characters, and the matter-of-fact sense of humor that makes up Ursula's signature style.

Title: Helliconia Spring (Helliconia, #1)
Author: Brian W. Aldiss
My Review:
I get what this book was going for. It told the story of a civilization developing under the influence of planarity forces. By telling it through the eyes of the primitive peoples it aimed to achieve a kind of biblical scope. Well it was successful in one sense--it was about as much fun to read as the bible.

The storytelling will spend years with a particular character, dwelling on one characters boring and brutal little life then unceremoniously flit past their demise and jump generations into the future. I think this was an attempt at giving the work an epic feel, but instead it lost my interest.

I regret sticking this one out to the end. I kept expecting it to bring it all together to make the tedious effort of watching these savages painstakingly crawl through towards civilization have some kind of grand meaning. Perhaps that's in the next book, but I'll pass, thanks.

Title: Anathem
Author: Neal Stephenson
My Review: This book demands your full attention, and quite a bit of intellectual work.  But it's worth it.

Author: Cory Doctorow

Title: Pride and Prejudice and Zombies (Pride and Prejudice and Zombies, #1)
Author: Seth Grahame-Smith

Title: The White Mountains (The Tripods, #1)
Author: John Christopher
My Review:
This was one of the first scifi books I picked up on my own when I was young. Many years later, I found myself thinking back on it and took the trouble to google random keywords to determine ...what was that book anyway?

I eventually found it and acquired a copy through BookMooch. I decided to pick it up again because I was looking for something light and fun, but I didn't set out with particularly high expectations. It's young adult fiction, I was a kid when I'd read it--revisited nostalgia rarely holds up to its remembered pedestal.

I was pleasantly surprised to discover that this one did. It is young adult fiction, so the writing was simple and PG-13. But I found that this didn't hurt the story. The book still painted a relatively complex world, there was lots of adventure, and it managed to have enough edge to be taken seriously.

All and all, it was exactly what I was hoping for, and I look forward to re-reading the rest of the series.

Title: The Hallowed Hunt (World of the Five Gods, #3)
Author: Lois McMaster Bujold
My Review:
This was working up to be my favorite of the Chalion series, but ended up going over the line from a complex and intriguing storyline to sprawling and aimless. The breadcrumbs of hints to unravel the mystery were meted out sparingly, leaving readers (and the characters for that matter) helplessly confused for most of the story. Until, at the end, all was revealed in droning chapters of exposition, leaving no room for readers to have puzzled out anything for themselves.

Aside from the poor pacing though, The Hallowed Hunt was a great story--the mechanics of the magics of the world were well constructed and aesthetically appealing. The characters had depth and distinctive personalities. And I found the interplay between the will of the gods, fate, and free will to come together into a satisfyingly pragmatic philosophy.

Title: The Curse of Chalion (World of the Five Gods, #1)
Author: Lois McMaster Bujold

Title: Treasure Box
Author: Orson Scott Card
My Review:
[a:Orson Scott Card|589|Orson Scott Card|http://photo.goodreads.com/authors/1237932066p2/589.jpg] is one of a handful of authors for whom I consider myself a dedicated fan. I've read, perhaps not most of his books, but a substantial chunk that makes up a representative sampling. So when I saw an unfamiliar Card book sitting on a friends shelf, I was naturally excited to borrow it.

This book reminds me quite a bit of [b:Lost Boys|40303|Lost Boys|Orson Scott Card|http://photo.goodreads.com/books/1185648847s/40303.jpg|1852188]. For the vast majority of the book it appears to be about entirely pedestrian people and events that leave you wondering why someone would bother writing a book about them, let alone making them. Then at the end a twist is revealed that I suppose is meant astonish and amaze. Instead it felt rushed and convoluted, not nearly making up for the snooze of the rest of the book.

Title: A Canticle for Leibowitz (St. Leibowitz, #1)
Author: Walter M. Miller Jr.
My Review:
It's funny to skim the reviews for A Canticle for Lebowitz. They oscillate between complaints of cynicism and praise for how uplifting it is; gripes about preachyness and applause for the candid portrayal of Catholicism; criticism of the characters and compliments of the same.

I think the reason behind the varied perspectives it the same thing that makes this book truly unique. The story is told with the dispassionate voice of an impartial observer. It is told in slices of time thousands of years apart when great historical shifts are occurring. And though the events taking place are monumental, as in real life, they may not appear to be to the people involved. Many of the players are the unwitting and unremarkable dopes who just happens to be around. With this gods-eye view, each reader finds a different meaning in what he reads.

The recurring themes that spoke to me were those of the insatiable hunger for knowledge, the struggles of faith, and the plodding inevitability of progress. To my mind, the core thesis of this story is the extraordinary capacity of the human race, both for ingenuity achievement and savage destruction. It is uplifting, cynical, both or neither.

This book is unlike any scifi book I've ever read, and I've come to think is a masterpiece.
